children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

10.1	The Office of the High Representative for the Least Developed Countries, Landlocked Developing Countries and Small Island Developing States is responsible for advocating, undertaking research and analysis, mobilizing support and resources, coordinating and reporting on the implementation of the programmes of action for the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States, as well as the achievement of other internationally agreed goals, including the Sustainable Development Goals. The mandate of the Office derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and decisions, including resolution 56/227, whereby the Assembly decided to establish the Office of the High Representative for the Least Developed Countries, Landlocked Developing Countries and Small Island Developing States.

10.2	The work of the Office is grounded in the three programmes of action, namely, resolution 76/258, whereby the Assembly endorsed the Doha Programme of Action for the Least Developed Countries for the Decade 2022–2031; resolution 78/317, whereby the General Assembly endorsed the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States: A Renewed Declaration for Resilient Prosperity; and resolution 79/233, whereby the Assembly endorsed the new Programme of Action for Landlocked Developing Countries for the Decade 2024–2034. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, including its global follow-up and review processes, is integral and complementary to the three programmes of action.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

10.3	In 2026, the least developed countries and their development partners will prepare for the comprehensive high-level midterm review of the implementation of the Doha Programme of Action for the Least Developed Countries. The central task ahead for the least developed countries and the international community is to strengthen partnerships that leave no one behind and boost progress towards the 2030 Agenda. Implementation of the provisions of the Doha Programme of Action by the least developed countries and their development partners will be prioritized, through the mobilization of commensurate resources and knowledge in support of accelerating their sustainable development and enhanced monitoring and accountability.

10.4	Building on the first year of implementation of the Programme of Action for Landlocked Developing Countries for the Decade 2024–2034, landlocked developing countries and their development partners will intensify efforts to operationalize its objectives and key deliverables. To support the successful implementation of the Programme of Action, in 2026 the Office will help with the mobilization of adequate financial, technical and capacity-building resources, undertake efforts to strengthen partnerships, and support countries with integrating the Programme of Action into national development plans and relevant global frameworks, with a view to addressing the specific vulnerabilities of landlocked developing countries. These measures will contribute to accelerating progress towards the 2030 Agenda through structural transformation, resilience-building and sustainable development in the landlocked developing countries.

10.5	In 2026, small island developing States and their development partners will commence the second full year of implementing the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States, focusing on key targets under its monitoring and evaluation framework, as well as the full operationalization of the small island developing States centre of excellence. The Office will actively advocate for the strengthening of global partnerships, including through the Small Island Developing States Global Business Network, utilization of the Multidimensional Vulnerability Index, enhanced access to concessional and climate financing, and by building the capacity of small island developing States national focal points to integrate the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States into national development plans. In addition, leveraging the Small Island Developing States Partnership Framework and engaging international financial institutions will be central to driving structural transformation and resilience-building. These efforts aim to deliver early, tangible results under the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States that address the unique challenges and special needs of these States.

10.6	The Office will utilize its strategic position in dealing with the three groups of countries to respond, with enhanced complementarity and coherence, to new and emerging development issues of potential concern, in particular those of a regional or global nature. In this regard, and in response to an assessment of functions under subprogramme 1, the Office is proposing to establish a new subprogramme – subprogramme 4, advocacy, outreach and analysis – to centralize those functions under a dedicated subprogramme that directly supports the three groups of countries. This restructuring would enable a more coordinated implementation of the programmes of action, while improving the Office’s capacity to produce analysis across regions and groups of countries, strengthen its research and data management capabilities and ensure more effective advocacy on shared development challenges. For example, it will mobilize support and contribute to building consensus, with an increased focus on policy recommendations to overcome the shared challenges of the most vulnerable countries, such as access to sustainable energy and broadband, on the basis of cross-cutting research carried out by the Office.

10.7	The new subprogramme will also strengthen connections in the follow-up and review arrangements of relevant United Nations conferences and processes, including the 2030 Agenda and the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, including by sharing lessons learned and best practices among the three groups of countries to enhance awareness of progress in implementing the three programmes of action. It will also mobilize resources to ensure that the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States have their voices heard in global deliberations. Resource mobilization efforts will also have an increased focus on joint initiatives, which can amplify impact among the three groups of countries. Furthermore, representatives of the most vulnerable countries will benefit from capacity-building activities, peer learning and the exchange of best practices, all on thematic areas relevant to the Sustainable Development Goals and to building resilience to future crises.

10.8	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global and regional levels, the Office will convene the inter-agency consultative groups for the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States. These groups will enable United Nations entities, funds and programmes and other international organizations to exchange information on their work, strengthen coordination of their activities and mount joint inter-agency activities. At the national level, the Office will cooperate with the networks of national focal points that act as an interface between the global, regional and national processes. The national focal points will promote coherence and coordination on issues relevant to the three groups of countries and facilitate policy formulation, implementation, follow-up and review of their programmes of action, ensuring full alignment with the 2030 Agenda and other global frameworks.

10.9	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will work closely with resident coordinators to promote the integration of the programmes of action into the United Nations strategic plans and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks and to act as an interface with Member States on the ground supporting the mainstreaming of the programmes of action into national strategies.
10.10	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	The security and political situation in the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States and in their surrounding regions is conducive to the implementation of the three programmes of action;
(b)	Continued international support measures in the areas of development finance, market access, technology and technical assistance are made available by development partners.

10.11	The Office will further explore the ways of cooperation, support and participation in the global efforts towards the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, with special attention given to the needs of those in vulnerable situations, women, young people, persons with disabilities and older persons.

10.12	The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. For example, the Office will implement its updated gender equality strategy for the period 2025–2029 with a view to further integrating gender equality and the empowerment of women into its work. In addition, as part of its monitoring and reporting work, the Office will include sex-disaggregated data and analysis across its reports for the three groups of countries.

10.13	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will continue to mainstream the rights of persons with disabilities and disability inclusion into its programme of work through the implementation of its disability inclusion strategy and action plan. The Office will conduct training sessions to increase the capacity of staff at all levels on disability inclusion in all areas of the Office’s work programme, including monitoring, reporting and advocacy activities, in accordance with its mandates.

children.text: Evaluation activities

10.16	An evaluation conducted by the Office on the effectiveness of the support to the network of national focal points of the Least Developed Countries, completed in 2024, has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

10.17	In response to the results of the above-mentioned evaluation, subprogramme 1 will provide more systematic, tailored and sustainable support to strengthen the role of national focal points in coordinating the implementation of the Doha Programme of Action at the national level, including through a more structured collaboration with resident coordinators in the least developed countries in preparation for the comprehensive high-level midterm review of the Doha Programme of Action.
10.18	An evaluation to be conducted by the Office on strengthening the capacity of landlocked developing countries to estimate transport and trade costs is planned for 2026.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Least developed countries
Objective

10.19	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen policies to eradicate poverty in the least developed countries and accelerate structural transformation of their economies; and to ensure effective graduation from the least developed country category.
Strategy
10.20	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide support to Member States in their intergovernmental processes relating to the priorities of the least developed countries, including by supporting the implementation of the Doha Programme of Action, including its deliverables, namely, an online university to support graduate and postgraduate university-level education in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, an investment support centre, a resilience-building mechanism, a Sustainable Graduation Support Facility and a system of food stockholding for the least developed countries on a regional and subregional basis, or alternative means, such as cash transfers, taking into account possible economic implications and risks;

(b)	Prepare research and analytical materials relating to the six key focus areas of the Doha Programme of Action and facilitate knowledge exchange and peer learning on critical enablers to poverty eradication and structural transformation, including by mainstreaming a gender perspective;

(c)	Promote resource mobilization, especially public and private financing, including innovative finance, for resilience-building, and monitor the road map for the accelerated implementation of the Doha Programme of Action, in partnership with the United Nations system, parliaments, civil society, the private sector, the media, academia and foundations in focus areas of the Doha Programme of Action, in preparation for the comprehensive high-level midterm review of the Doha Programme of Action;

(d)	Lead the inter-agency task forces on: (i) least developed country graduation, including by organizing workshops and technical support on establishing consultative mechanisms with development partners and preparing smooth transition strategies, and by facilitating peer learning between graduated and graduating countries; and (ii) developing operational guidelines for the United Nations system’s support to least developed countries in conflict and post-conflict situations;
(e)	Monitor sectoral policy developments of the intergovernmental processes of relevant international and regional organizations, including multilateral development banks;

(f)	Build the capacity of national focal points to implement and monitor the Doha Programme of Action, through annual meetings and training programmes, to share experiences and best practices, including through the application of guidelines for mainstreaming and monitoring the implementation of the Doha Programme of Action, and with a more structured collaboration with resident coordinators, in preparation for the comprehensive high-level midterm review of the Doha Programme of Action;
(g)	Partner with the Technology Bank for the Least Developed Countries to strengthen science, technology and innovation capacity, including in graduated and graduating countries.
10.21	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Least developed countries accelerating progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and achieving the focus areas of the Doha Programme of Action and other internationally agreed development goals;
(b)	Graduating countries making a smooth transition out of the least developed country category;
(c)	Stronger alignment of intergovernmental discussions with the priorities of least developed countries, reflecting a deeper understanding of their realities;

(d)	Greater accountability of least developed countries, development partners, international organizations, civil society and the private sector in the implementation of the commitments of the Doha Programme of Action.
Programme performance in 2024
Doha Programme of Action integrated into national development plans of least developed countries

10.22	The subprogramme supports least developed countries with the integration of the Doha Programme of Action into national development strategies, ensuring alignment with country-specific goals and facilitating effective implementation of the Doha Programme of Action. To catalyse this process, the subprogramme developed comprehensive guidelines for the mainstreaming and monitoring of the Doha Programme of Action. These guidelines also serve as a resource for United Nations country teams, enabling targeted support. In 2024, the subprogramme organized a strategic training programme for national focal points in least developed countries, in partnership with resident coordinators. The three-day event provided in-depth orientation on the Doha Programme of Action mainstreaming and monitoring tools, facilitated knowledge exchange on best practices and identified critical capacity-building needs.

Result 1: improved tertiary education options in least developed countries through an online university for science, technology, engineering and mathematics education – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

10.24	The subprogramme’s work contributed to advanced consultations on the establishment of an online university for science, technology, engineering and mathematics education for the least developed countries, which did not meet the planned target of Member States agreeing to a proposal to establish an online university dedicated to students from least developed countries. The target was not met due to additional consultations with relevant stakeholders taking place to facilitate the development of recommendations for the report of the Secretary-General.

children.text: Result 3: strengthened resilience to external shocks in the least developed countries – Proposed programme plan for 2026

10.28	To address the various challenges facing the least developed countries, the subprogramme prepared a report on the status of multi-hazard early warning systems in least developed countries, which contained proposals toward strengthening resilience to external shocks.
Lessons learned and planned change

10.29	The lesson for the subprogramme, on the basis of the findings of the report, was the need to prioritize the strengthening risk governance, disaster risk knowledge, operational systems and infrastructure, and to enhance the capacity and coverage of early warning systems in least developed countries. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will support those countries in preparing and implementing national adaptation plans and related projects, share knowledge and build capacity on the means to build financial resilience through insurance and other instruments.

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Landlocked developing countries
Objective

10.32	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen policies and capacities to improve the connectivity of landlocked developing countries, with the aim of supporting their sustainable development, reduce their trade transaction costs, enhance their regional cooperation and increase their regional, subregional and global trade, and strengthen their institutions and social and environmental protection; and to increase structural transformation in landlocked developing countries for sustainable development.
Strategy
10.33	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide support to Member States in their intergovernmental processes relating to the priorities of landlocked developing countries, including by supporting the implementation of the new programme of action for landlocked developing countries;

(b)	Undertake research and analytical assessments to assist landlocked developing countries in enacting policies conducive to their developmental priorities in line of those contained in the new programme of action for landlocked developing countries;
(c)	Mobilize international support for the implementation of the new programme of action for landlocked developing countries and other relevant agendas;

(d)	Coordinate, monitor and assess progress made in relation to the programme of action for landlocked developing countries, including through the inter-agency consultative group on landlocked developing countries;

(e)	Build capacity of the national focal points of landlocked developing countries, in collaboration with the resident coordinators, to facilitate the mainstreaming of the programme of action for landlocked developing countries into their national development plans.
10.34	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Increased support towards landlocked developing countries from the international community to address the needs and challenges arising from their lack of direct access to the sea and transit constraints;
(b)	Increased adoption and implementation by landlocked developing countries of initiatives to enhance transit, connectivity, trade facilitation and climate change adaptation and mitigation;

(c)	Landlocked developing countries devising, formulating and implementing policies that promote economic diversification, integration into global and regional value chains, and structural economic transformation;
(d)	Strengthened social protection for all groups of population in landlocked developing countries, including through access to decent jobs.
Programme performance in 2024
Increased implementation of the World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement by landlocked developing countries

10.35	Implementation of the World Trade Organization (WTO) Trade Facilitation Agreement can help reduce trade costs and enhance trade competitiveness. The subprogramme increased its advocacy in support of the implementation of trade facilitation measures. The subprogramme collaborated with WTO to organize events focusing on trade facilitation, including during the WTO Global Review of Aid for Trade, the WTO Committee on Trade and Development and the WTO Public Forum event. These efforts contributed to an increased number of trade facilitation measures implemented by landlocked developing countries in 2024.
10.36	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 10.II).
Figure 10.II
Performance measure: rate of implementation of the World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement by landlocked developing countries
(Percentage)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: accelerated progress towards sustainable development in landlocked developing countries – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

10.37	The subprogramme’s work contributed to preparations for the third United Nations Conference on the Landlocked Developing Countries and intergovernmental processes leading to the adoption of the programme of action for landlocked developing countries by the General Assembly in December 2024, which did not meet the planned target of at least two landlocked developing countries initiating action to mainstream the new programme of action. The target was not met due to the postponement of the third United Nations Conference on the Landlocked Developing Countries, which contributed to the delayed adoption of the programme of action.

10.41	Landlocked developing countries often experience increased trade costs and reduced economic competitiveness. The subprogramme has undertaken research and capacity-building activities aimed at promoting freedom of transit and strengthening regional collaboration, including advocating for smoother and more efficient cross-border movement of goods.
Lessons learned and planned change

10.42	The lesson for the subprogramme was that more targeted and inclusive consultations among key stakeholders would help ensure that policies and procedures are adapted to the specific needs of landlocked developing countries. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will enhance stakeholder engagement, including Member States, regional organizations and international institutions, in the process of supporting the work of the high-level panel of experts.

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Small island developing States
Objective
10.45	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to increase sustainable development and economic, social and environmental resilience in small island developing States.
Strategy
10.46	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Mobilize support for the special case of small island developing States in achieving sustainable development by engaging with development partners, international financial institutions and the private sector;
(b)	Support resource mobilization efforts for small island developing States in priority areas, including through a targeted resource mobilization strategy and by developing tailored policy tools;

(c)	Provide structured support through the Small Island Developing States Partnership Framework for the facilitation of collaborative partnerships, especially between small island developing States and the private sector;

(d)	Strengthen coherence and coordination at the national, regional and global levels, including by providing more structured support to the small island developing States national focal points network and increasing coordination between United Nations entities supporting those States;
(e)	Develop and strengthen the implementation frameworks for the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States.
10.47	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Strengthened international support measures aimed at enabling small island developing States to implement the 2030 Agenda, the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States, the Paris Agreement and other priorities of those States for sustainable development;
(b)	Enhanced access to finance for small island developing States;
(c)	Small island developing States formulating and implementing policies that promote sustainable development and make progress towards the achievement of internationally agreed development goals.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened assessment of multidimensional vulnerabilities for small island developing States

10.48	Small island developing States remain a special case for sustainable development and have continued challenges in achieving sustained high levels of economic growth, owing in part to their vulnerabilities to the ongoing negative impacts of environmental challenges and other external economic and financial shocks. To better assess the vulnerabilities of small island developing States, the subprogramme continued to support the process to advance a multidimensional vulnerability index, which culminated in the adoption of the index by the General Assembly. The subprogramme also supported advocacy efforts with international financial institutions, international organizations and multilateral development banks to consider using the multidimensional vulnerability index, as appropriate, as a complement to their existing practices and policies, in line with their respective mandates.
10.49	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 10.9).

children.text: Result 3: small island developing States use the monitoring and reporting framework for the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States to inform national planning strategies – Proposed programme plan for 2026

10.54	To help develop national capacities for systematic monitoring and evaluation of the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States, the subprogramme conducted consultations and analysis with a range of relevant stakeholders, development partners and financing institutions, and proposed the development of a toolkit.
Lessons learned and planned change

10.55	The lesson for the subprogramme was that practical support to small island developing States was particularly useful to help countries develop national monitoring and evaluation capacities. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide practical support to small island developing States and development partners to advance the use of the implementation toolkit, with a focus on facilitating the monitoring of the implementation of the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States, and to inform the design and implementation of targeted and effective sustainable development policies.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Advocacy, outreach and analysis
Objective

10.58	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the sustainable development priorities and the shared challenges of the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States.
Strategy
10.59	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Generate data analysis and insights and publish analytical research for the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States, including cross-cutting flagship reports, analytical briefs and trend analysis, on topics that align with and support the advancement of three programmes of action and global development agendas;

(b)	Provide, in preparing for intergovernmental processes, substantive support on the regional and country specificities of research and trend analysis for ongoing and emerging issues affecting the three groups of countries;
(c)	Build research partnerships and networks, particularly in emerging areas and for enhanced data collection and analysis among and within the three groups of countries;

(d)	Develop outreach campaigns using, data-driven storytelling and multimedia products, on the specific challenges and opportunities of the three groups of countries and the priorities of the three programmes of action;

(e)	Advocate for sustained and adequate international support for the three programmes of action and the integration of these priorities into global agendas by organizing high-level events, convening multi-stakeholder dialogues and engaging in targeted advocacy with decision-makers in intergovernmental forums.
10.60	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Strengthened implementation of evidence-based policies and decision-making by the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States;
(b)	Increased understanding and engagement of target audiences, particularly decision-makers, in support of and for the advancement of the priorities of the three programmes of action.
Planned result for 2026
10.61	The planned result for 2026 is a new result.
Strengthened integration of the three programmes of action into relevant intergovernmental processes
10.62	The Office amplifies the voices of the most vulnerable countries through targeted advocacy, by raising global awareness and by driving action on their unique challenges and priorities.
Lessons learned and planned change

10.63	The lesson for the Office was that there were further opportunities to support countries in integrating the three programmes of action into other intergovernmental processes, including monitoring progress on globally agreed goals and targets. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will increase its advocacy efforts to promote the use of research and analytical tools that can support policymakers in evidence-based decision-making. For example, the subprogramme will advocate with national focal points to showcase best practices from the implementation of the programmes of action, in preparation for countries’ participation in the voluntary national review process. The subprogramme will also facilitate speaking engagements and support side-events to promote the integration of the programmes of action into the voluntary national review process during intergovernmental meetings, such as the high-level political forum.
10.64	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 10.IV).
Figure 10.IV

text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Overview

10.66	Pursuant to paragraph 20 of General Assembly resolution 77/262, the Office carried out a spending review as part of the preparation of its proposed programme budget for 2026. Under the strategic guidance of the High Representative and with the engagement of all programme managers, a review was carried out for the executive direction and management component and for each of the Office’s subprogrammes. The review included a comprehensive analysis of historical trends in the distribution and expenditure of non-post resources and the Office’s post complement and functional profiles, with a view to identifying efficiencies and resource realignments to support the optimal implementation of the Office’s mandate and the achievement of results, as set forth in the proposed programme plan for 2026.

10.67	As a result of an analysis of prior expenditure of non-post resources, current performance and projected future requirements against the Office’s mandated activities, a redistribution of resources across various objects of expenditure under the executive direction and management component is proposed for 2026, as follows:

(a)	Under executive direction and management, a cost-neutral net internal redeployment of $16,100 ($9,400 from contractual services, $2,500 from general operating expenses and $4,200 from supplies and materials) to furniture and equipment is proposed, to address increased costs associated with replacing office information technology equipment that is no longer under warranty. This adjustment is aimed at ensuring business continuity in support of Member States. The review also identified efficiency gains through reduced mobile phone usage, the cancellation of Cisco phone subscriptions and the consolidation of voice services using Microsoft Teams for the front office of the Under-Secretary-General. Additional savings relating to the reduced cost of centrally provided information technology support under the service-level agreement with the Office of Information and Communications Technology were identified;

(b)	Within general operating expenses, a further reallocation of $21,000 is proposed, moving funds from communications and miscellaneous services to the provision for meeting and technical services provided by the Broadcast and Conference Support Section. This adjustment responds to the increase in the cost of services in recent years and is necessary to support the effective organization of expert group meetings, panel discussions and special events at Headquarters and other locations for the benefit of the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States.

10.68	With regard to other non-post resources under executive direction and management and the Office’s subprogrammes, consumption patterns over the past five years were reviewed against the budgets for travel of staff, travel of representatives and consultants. While the analysis resulted in negligible changes to the distribution of resources, all subprogramme managers placed renewed emphasis on the importance of supporting the participation of the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States in face-to-face meetings relevant to the implementation of their programmes of action. In view of the level of non-post resources, compared with the broad scope of the programmes of action, the subprogramme managers reiterated that they regularly sought to collaborate, plan and align events across all subprogrammes, as well as with United Nations and other partner entities. Programme managers routinely pursue measures aimed at increasing efficiencies, such as organizing inter-agency consultative group meetings through Microsoft Teams and other virtual platforms, arranging back-to-back meetings, organizing meetings on cross-cutting issues for all three groups and using recorded messages of the High Representative, whenever appropriate or feasible, to make the most efficient use of resources by reducing travel costs and duration, while seeking to maximize participation.

10.69	In response to the recommendation of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions set out in paragraph IV.41 of its first report on the proposed programme budget for 2025 (A/79/7) and endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/257, the Office carried out an independent review of its structure, in which the Office’s approved organization chart for 2025 was assessed against its actual operations, and a recommendation was made with respect to the best option for revising the organization chart to align resources with the Office’s mandates in the most effective way. The main issue with the Office’s current structure identified during the review is one of imbalance. Subprogramme 1 (Least developed countries) has a total of 17 posts (14 Professional and 3 General Service). Two cross-cutting functional areas (the Policy Development and Coordination, Monitoring and Reporting Service and the Advocacy and Outreach Unit) are also located within subprogramme 1; the total number of posts of those areas comprise 1 Chief of Service (D-1), 4 Professional staff and 1 General Service (Other level) staff. Subprogramme 1 therefore comprises a total of 23 posts, which is more than half of all the Office’s posts (53.5 per cent). Drawing on standard evaluation criteria to understand and analyse an intervention (relevance, coherence, effectiveness, efficiency, impact and sustainability), the independent review offered an informed assessment of the pros and cons of two alternative strategies: maintaining the status quo or restructuring the Office’s organization chart, which had remained unchanged since the Office was established. The independent review underscored the importance of a comprehensive, well-‍resourced and highly competent subprogramme 1. Nevertheless, maintaining the status quo would bring into question the adequacy of resourcing and input for subprogramme 2 (Landlocked developing countries), subprogramme 3 (Small island developing States) and the core functions of advocacy, outreach, research and analysis performed by the Office, which cover all three groups.

10.70	The core recommendation of the independent review is to establish a fourth subprogramme, focused on advocacy, outreach and analysis, alongside the existing three subprogrammes, which would improve the coherence of the structure of the Office. The new Advocacy, Outreach and Analysis Section has been conceived as a horizontal, cross-cutting service entity that would deliver cross-cutting and distinct advocacy and analytical outputs, services and deliverables to the Office of the High Representative and to each of the other three subprogrammes. This proposal would entail the redeployment of five posts delivering cross-cutting services, as described in annex II. The independent review also recommended the redeployment of the Chief of Service (D-1) and one General Service (Other level) post from the Policy Development and Coordination, Monitoring and Reporting Service, which is also within subprogramme 1, to executive direction and management, given that the Chief is traditionally responsible for overseeing the work of all subprogrammes, not just that of subprogramme 1. As a result of the proposed changes, the Service would cease to exist, and the functions of the Advocacy and Outreach Unit would be redeployed to subprogramme 4. These redeployments would be enabled by the redistribution of functions within subprogramme 1 and from that subprogramme to the new subprogramme 4 and the absorption of cross-cutting functions by the new subprogramme. Moving the cross-cutting functions of advocacy and communication and the capacities in data analysis and research to a dedicated section under subprogramme 4 would increase effectiveness and synergies between workstreams and optimize the use of existing capacities to support the three groups of countries, individually and collectively, through a more seamless operational modality in which the Office’s strategic position is better utilized to address the shared challenges and key development issues facing the three groups of countries and the increased demand for the Office’s support to monitor the three programmes of action.

10.71	The subprogramme managers reviewed detailed staffing tables and the reporting lines of all staff, along with justifications for the continuing need for each post, in line with the approved programme of work. The workforce review was enriched with information on the current composition of each subprogramme across a number of dimensions, including the distribution of staff by grade, the projected retirements by level and by year through 2060, and the current vacancy rates by count and by level, in order to comprehensively review the changing nature of the workforce and identify any current or future opportunities to optimize or enhance organizational structures. While changes to the grades of existing posts were not recommended as a result of the spending review, subprogramme managers reiterated that a desirable outcome would be to move posts responsible for cross-cutting functions out of subprogramme 1. The review also involved an analysis of opportunities to strengthen future skill requirements, including in such areas as data analytics and management, strategic communications and strategic foresight, so that such requirements are fully considered and reflected, where appropriate, in the underlying job descriptions. The results of the spending review will enable the Office to deliver mandates more effectively in the future by strengthening workforce capabilities in the aforementioned areas and rejuvenating the workforce through the use of retirement projections.

Technical adjustments
10.75	As shown in table 10.18 (1), resource changes reflect a net decrease of $592,800, as follows:

(a)	Executive direction and management (net increase of $77,200). The increase of $84,400 under posts relates to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for the Programme Management Officer (P-3) established in 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/257, which was subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for newly established posts. It is offset in part by the decrease of $7,200 under non-post resources relating to the removal of the non-recurrent provision associated with the furniture and equipment for the post that were approved for 2025;

(b)	Subprogramme 1, Least developed countries (increase of $98,700). The increase of $98,700 under posts relates to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for the Programme Management Officer (P-4) established in 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/257, which was subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for newly established posts;

(c)	Subprogramme 2, Landlocked developing countries (decrease of $518,700). The decrease of $518,700 under non-post resources relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions for general temporary assistance ($205,800), consultants ($114,700) and experts ($198,200) that were approved for 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/233;

(d)	Subprogramme 3, Small island developing States (decrease of $250,000). The decrease of $250,000 under non-post resources relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions for general temporary assistance ($189,400) and consultants ($60,600) that were approved for 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolutions 78/317 and 78/322.
New and expanded mandates

10.76	As shown in table 10.18 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $302,600 under subprogramme 2, Landlocked developing countries, relating to additional requirements under general temporary assistance ($266,480) for a Senior Economic Affairs Officer (P-5) and under contractual services ($36,100), pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/233.
Other changes
10.77	As shown in table 10.18 (1), resource changes reflect cost-neutral redeployments, as follows:
(a)	Executive direction and management (net increase of $184,700):

(i)	The increase of $345,700 under posts relates to the cost-neutral inward redeployment of the Chief of Service (D-1) and one Staff Assistant (General Service (Other level)) from subprogramme 1, as explained in paragraphs 10.68 and 10.69 above and as detailed in annex II;

(ii)	The decrease of $161,000 under posts relates to the outward redeployment of one Associate Data Analyst (P-2) to subprogramme 4 as explained in paragraphs 10.68 and 10.69 above and as detailed in annex II;
(iii) 	In addition, the resources reflect the cost-neutral redeployment of resources detailed in paragraph 10.66 (a) above;
(b)	Subprogramme 1, Least developed countries ( decrease of $1,385,600):

(i)	The decrease of $1,271,500 under posts relates to the outward redeployment of one Senior Economic Affairs Officer (P-5), two Public Information Officers (P-4 and P-3) and one Statistician (P-3) to subprogramme 4, and of the Chief of Service (D-1) and one Staff Assistant (General Service (Other level)) to executive direction and management, as explained in paragraphs 10.68 and 10.69 above and as detailed in annex II;

(ii)	The decrease of $114,100 under non-post resources relates to the outward redeployment of provisions under travel of staff ($36,900) and contractual services ($77,200) associated with the redeployment of the functions of the Advocacy and Outreach Unit to subprogramme 4;
(c)	Subprogramme 4, Advocacy outreach and analysis (increase of $1,200,900):

(i)	The increase of $1,086,800 under posts relates to the cost-neutral inward redeployment of the post from executive direction and management and the four posts from subprogramme 1, as indicated above and as detailed in annex II;

(ii)	The increase of $114,100 under non-post resources relates to the inward redeployment of provisions under travel of staff ($36,900) and contractual services ($77,200) associated with the inward redeployment of the functions of the Advocacy and Outreach Unit indicated above from subprogramme 1.
Extrabudgetary resources

10.78	As reflected in tables 10.18 (2) and 10.19 (2), extrabudgetary resources are estimated at $3,239,100. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for three posts (1 P-5, 1 P-4 and 1 General Service (Other level)) for carrying out activities relating to follow-up to the Fifth United Nations Conference on the Least Developed Countries, the third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries and the fourth International Conference on Small Island Developing States. The anticipated decrease of $1,995,400 in 2026 relates to the removal of non-recurrent resources raised in 2025 to support Member States’ participation at the third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries, to be held in August 2025.

10.79	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Under-Secretary-General and High Representative, who has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
Executive direction and management

10.80	The Under-Secretary-General and High Representative is responsible for the overall leadership and direction of the Office in the implementation of its mandates and approved programme of work under section 10. The High Representative engages in high-level consultations with Member States, organizations of the United Nations system, multilateral and regional financial institutions, the private sector, and civil society groups and academia and supports the Economic and Social Council and the General Assembly in their reviews and assessments of progress achieved in the implementation of the programmes of action for the three groups of countries and the 2030 Agenda, as it relates to these countries.

10.81	The Office advises the Under-Secretary-General and High Representative on issues of policy and management; acts as a focal point for information on all aspects of the work of the Office and ensures that such information is disseminated internally and projected externally, as appropriate; and consults, negotiates and coordinates with other departments, offices, funds and programmes, as well as with non-United Nations entities, on matters of common concern. The Office is headed by a Director (D-2), who deputizes for and is accountable to the Under-Secretary-General and High Representative.

10.82	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Office is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. As the secretariat for the third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries, to be held in August 2025, the Office will use the Secretariat Sustainable Events Checklist as a guiding framework to ensure that the conference meets high environmental sustainability standards. Insights and best practices drawn from major recent events, including the Fifth United Nations Conference on the Least Developed Countries and the fourth International Conference on Small Island Developing States, will further inform and enhance the environmental sustainability strategies for the third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries. The Office remains committed to monitoring its carbon dioxide emissions associated with air travel. Such monitoring enables informed decision-making and the benchmarking of the Office’s air travel emissions as a proportion of total carbon dioxide emissions reported by United Nations entities, facilitating continuous improvement in emissions management.

10.83	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 10.21. Significant progress was made with respect to compliance with advance booking for air travel. The Office will continue to make efforts to improve its timely submission of documentation.
